sec.title: Analysing the Chinook Database using SQLite and R
sec.p: This example uses the Chinook Database which represents a hypothetical a digital media store, including tables for artists, albums, media tracks, invoices and customers. We chose it for this example because it:

list-item.p: is relatively small, so doesn’t bloat the examples repo
has several tables, so is good for illustraing joins

sec.p: Let’s start by querying the sqlite_master table to get a list of the tables in the database,

alternatives.code: SELECT name FROM sqlite_master WHERE type='table'

sec.p: We can also inspect the structure of each table by looking at the sql column,

alternatives.code: SELECT sql FROM sqlite_master WHERE name IN ('Album', 'Artist')

sec.p: OK, so lets look at the top ten artists in terms of numbers of albums,

alternatives.code: SELECT Name, count(AlbumId) AS Albums FROM Artist LEFT JOIN Album ON Artist.ArtistId=Album.ArtistId GROUP BY Name ORDER BY Albums DESC LIMIT 10

sec.p: What are the most common first letters for album titles? Let’s count the number of albums having each first letter using SQL and then plot the result in R. We want to save the result of the SQL query and in Stencila we can do it by simply assigning the result to a variable albums_per_letter:

alternatives.code: albums_per_letter = SELECT substr(Title,1,1) AS Letter, count(AlbumId) AS Albums FROM Album GROUP BY Letter
